Browser Vendors 'Working Together on Interop 2022' â€” A new collaboration from Apple, Bocoup, Google, Microsoft, Mozilla and others to improve interoperability of (mostly visual) web technologies. Thereâ€™s a dashboard here showing how various browser engines are doing across all focusÂ areas.

A New Speed Milestone for Chrome â€” How the â€˜M99â€™ release of Chrome saw substantial increases to the speed of Chrome across all majorÂ platforms. "Overall, since launching Chrome on M1-based Macs in late 2020, Chrome is now 43% faster than it was just 17 months ago!"

  • Here are the release notes for Safari Technology Preview Release 141, which adds support for overflow: clip.

Frontend Focus

#â€‹531 â€” March 2, 2022 | Read on the web

New CSS Features in 2022 â€” It looks like 2022 is shaping up to be a great year for CSS, as weâ€™ve got a ton of new features on the horizon, like Container Queries, the accent-colour property, subgrid, scroll timeline, and much more. This article goes over each thing in detail. Well worth checking out to stay sharp on whatâ€™s new across theÂ spec.

Michelle Barker

Ready to Switch Careers to Software Engineering? â€” Springboard offers a comprehensive software engineering bootcamp. Work one-on-one with a mentor to learn key aspects of both front-end and back-end development, databases, data structures, and algorithms. Apply to Springboard's Software Engineering Bootcamp to start yourÂ journey.

Springboard sponsor

A New Year, A New MDN â€” Today I learnt that MDN is home to over 44,000 articles. Hereâ€™s a look at how the MDN team went about creating â€œa more holistic experience for our users, with an emphasis on improved navigability and a universal look andÂ feelâ€. Always great to see one of the top Web developer resources taking a big stepÂ forward.

Mozilla

Explain the First 10 Lines of Twitter's Source Code to Me â€” An interview question for a frontend role that seems straightforward enough, but thereâ€™s actually plenty to unpack and considerÂ here. (Whether it's a good interview question is a different story, ofÂ course.)

Anand Chowdhary

  • Could EU 'Qualified Website Authentication Certificate' plans result in 'less secure' certificates in browsers?

items.content:
Frontend Focus

#â€‹530 â€” February 23, 2022 | Read on the web

ğŸ”’ Â How Everything We're Told About Website Identity Assurance is Wrong â€” Dives into how website trust is communicated online (certificates, SSL, and the like) â€” and how such things can often prove to beÂ misleading.

Troy Hunt

Using Flexbox to Create a Dynamic Line Separator â€” How to make use of the default flexbox stretching behaviour to create a dynamic line separator. A solid tutorial told in Ahmadâ€™s usual accessible style, with code examples and visuals to help move thingsÂ along.

Ahmad Shadeed

Walkthrough of an Easy Angular Data Grid with Examples â€” You could write your own data grid, but why would you when this one already exists. See how easy it is to set up, bind data, group, sort, page, and more. Fiddle with the live samples or install it and try it for yourself, but donâ€™t missÂ it.

Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

Testing Pipeline 101 For Frontend Testing â€” If you want to introduce a testing build routine hereâ€™s a quick look at how to get on the right track â€” specifically with the help of some testing frameworks and GitHubÂ actions.

Ramona Schwerin

â–¶Â Â Builder a Greener Web â€” A 20-minute talk on the environmental impact of our sites and what considerations you may want to take into account when it comes to the carbon footprint of your digitalÂ projects.

Michelle Barker

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Fresh data suggests that Microsoft Edge is on the verge of overtaking Safari as the world's second most popular desktop browser.
  • This is a neat tip I'd forgotten about: You can shave up to 90% off the size of Google Fonts by declaring only the characters you actually need.
  • This 'manifesto' aims to highlight the importance of including bidirectional text in your product.
  • An analysis of top 1 million websites found 21 million tracking cookies belonging to 1200 companies ğŸ˜±

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

A Complete Guide to CSS Cascade Layers â€” Weâ€™ve featured a few good links and resources on this topic over the last few weeks, and this one seems to be the most thorough yet â€” covering its origins, how it works, use cases, and more. Quick refresher: The @layer feature allows us to define explicit contained layers of specificity (so we can avoidÂ hacks).

Miriam Suzanne

Subsetting Font Awesome to Improve Performance â€” How to go about removing any unused glyphs from the font files so that it reduces the overall fileÂ size.

Adam Rackis

Survivorship Bias in Web Performance â€” Why your analytics shows your site as faster than it is, and why First Contentful Paint (FCP) is a particularly good metric to optimizeÂ for.

Simon Hearne

Are You Up to Date on Webhooks? ğŸ¤” â€” Learn how to structure and version webhooks, how to build a webhooks backend, and why you should use them. ReadÂ more.

Hook Relay sponsor

The No-Nonsense Styling Method â€” A set of guidelines compiled to make styling â€œless surprising and more predictableâ€. Specifically, it aims to increase the scalability, maintainability, readability, and ease of change ofÂ yourÂ CSS.

Ben Lorantfy

Animating-In a Newly Added Element â€” Using @keyframes just might remove the need for JavaScript when animating newly added DOMÂ elements.

Stephanie Eckles

What Makes Writing More Readable? â€” Does a really good job of highlighting the benefits of plain language (with a neat toggle to see the before/after). The advice here is obviously applicable in several areas of life, but well worth considering from a web copy angleÂ too.

Rebecca Monteleone and Jamie Brew

How to Make 'Slanted' Containers with CSS in 3 Steps
Dave Seidman

Creating a Read Progress Bar in React and TailwindCSS
Anshuman Bhardwaj

Jobs

Senior Frontend Engineer (React) â€” Remote / NYC â€” We're the leading spend management platform for businesses. Small cross-functional front-end operations using React andÂ TypeScript.
Ramp

Frontend Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools & Resources

Simple.css: A 'Classless' CSS Framework â€” Similar to SPCSS, which we shared previously. This one includes dark mode and some nice typographic features for quickly setting up landing pages or other simpleÂ projects: "By 'classless' I mean that there are no CSS classes anywhere in the CSS orÂ theÂ HTML." SemanticÂ HTMLÂ FTW!

Simple.css

Stylo: An Open Source WYSIWYG Rich Text Editor for JavaScript â€” Based on a web component, no dependencies, and you can configure the default toolbar to suit your appâ€™sÂ needs. Being able to edit the project's homepage is a neat touch.

David Dal Busco

Project Management for Software Teams Has Never Been Easier

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Atropos: Touch-Friendly 3D Parallax Hover Effects â€” The easiest and fastest way to fool the eye into thinking the screen has somehow developed three-dimensional capabilities (and, admittedly, annoy some users - so be careful) is to use parallex effects as demonstrated on theÂ project'sÂ homepage.

Vladimir Kharlampidi

Mailwind: Use Tailwind CSS to Design HTML Emails â€” Just add Tailwindâ€™s utility classes as you normally would, then install and run Mailwind via npm to generate the accompanying CSS or inlinedÂ HTML.

Soheil Rashidi

A Pure CSS Working Stopwatch â€” This is a neat little CSS stopwatch demo that actually works â€” which is possible thanks to the Houdini @property (as such it only works in Chrome and Edge rightÂ now). Give it a try.

Jhey Tompkins codepen
